This application shows the use of an accelerometer, a gyroscope, a magnetometer, a light sensor, a proximity sensor and a GPS as useful devices in a physics lab.\n
Sensor Mobile is an application designed as a viewer and monitor for sensors built in your Android dispositive.\n
Select sampling frequency, number of samples per second.

It is a device that measures acceleration, ie the variation of the speed of an object. It also allows you to measure the acceleration of gravity.\n Acceleration is measured in meters per second squared (m/s²) or in G units (g =9.8 m/s2).\n

Accelerometers used in mobile phones are MEMS (Microelectromechanical Systems) devices built in a silicon chip. It works by measuring variations in capacity of a capacitor built by two confronted fixed metal plates and by a dielectric material.
 One of those plates is movable so that when force is applied on the device, the capacitance changes. Capacity increases or decreases depending on the movement.
 A sensor measures the variations in capacity, that are proportional to the applied force, and sends this data to the microprocessor device to determine the acceleration applied. The Microprocessor saves this data in a data base and compares new data with a range of values of reference which are related to a determined force and acceleration.
 Acceleration is a vector magnitude which needs values of its three components in its three directions x, y and z. That is why there are three different devices as described above to measure acceleration in x, y and z directions.
An accelerometer allows you to detect the position of the mobile phone in order to rotate the screen.\n
The accelerometer measures the acceleration applied on the device and its properties are summarized in the table.\n
A gyroscope is a mechanical device which allows us to measure, keep and change orientation of a device by measuring rotational speed in rad/s.\n

Gyroscopes used in mobile phones are MEMS (Microelectromechanical Systems) devices built in a silicon chip. It works by measuring variations in capacity of a capacitor that occur when a small mass, which is integrated in the mechanism, moves by means of a rotation.
 The gyroscope, once set in motion, always maintains the orientation and gets oriented to true north. Thus, the gyroscope gives us a precise orientation, it indicates the movement that it has on its axes and gives us the exact position regarding the starting point.
 As angular speed is a vector magnitude, values from its three components (x, y and z) are needed to define it.
The gyroscope allows you to rotate your device screen.\n

The gyroscope measures the rotational speed of the device by using x, y and z axis. Values taken by gyroscope can be positive or negative. When observing the origin of a position along the positive side of an axis, if rotation is counter-clockwise around the axis, the final value is considered positive. If rotation is made on the opposite direction, value is considered negative. We can also determine the direction of a gyroscope value.\n
It is an electronic device able to quantify the intensity of a magnetic field (µT).\n

Magnetometer is a common electromagnet with an iron core and a coil of wire wound around.
 Magnetism varies depending on places due to differences in earth magnet field (magnetosphere) and it could be produced by differences in rocks composition. Magnetometers are frequently integrated in spacecrafts and they are also used in geological explorations to search for anticlinal structures.
 As acceleration is a vector magnitude, values from its three directions (x, y and z) are needed. That is why there are three different devices as described above for each direction (x, y and z).
It can be used as a compass and metal detector.\n
The most important use of the magnetometer (described in table) in Android systems is to implement the compass.\n
It is an electronic device which measures changes in light intensity. Generally, the chosen unity is lux.\n

A light sensor includes a photoelectric transducer which converts light into an electric signal. It can also include necessary hardware for treating light signal and formatting the output signal.\n The most common light sensor is LDR -Light Dependent Resistor-. A LDR is basically a resistor that changes its resistance when light intensity changes.\n
It is used for adjusting screen brightness in relation to the ambient light intensity.\n
The system uses an ambient light sensor, described in table, to detect ambient illumination and adjust automatically screen brightness.\n
It is a sensor able to measure in centimeters (cm) the distance between the mobile phone and another object.\n

It is built by an infrared LED and an infrared receiver. When an object is located in a minimum distance to the device, the infrared light emitted by the infrared LED is reflected and captured by the infrared receiver. By this reflection and the reception of infrared light, objects can be detected by the system.\n

When the device is close to our ear for answering a call, the screen of the device will shut down to save battery.\n And, what is more, when touching screen by accident while answering a call, nothing will occur because the proximity sensor can block the screen to avoid this trouble.\n

Proximity sensor can quantify distance between the device and other object. Device can detect if the user is holding the device closely or not (see table) and determine if the user is in a call in order to shut the screen down during that call.\n
It is the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS), which allows us to determine position of an object, human being or vehicle on earth.\n

GPS works by triangulation, a mathematician principle that determines the exact position of a point by knowing distance from it to other three known location points. Theoretically, three different satellites are needed to calculate position, speed and height of the receiver.\n
The GPS can be used to show paths, routes and locations.\n
There are two buttons on the main screen:\n

Data measurement:
 	In this section, the sensors will be displayed with its measurements.
 Loading graphics:
 	All files with saved graphics will be displayed.
 Besides these two options, there are four more sections pressing the menu button:
Sensor device: in this option all sensors of the device are collected in a list with the following characteristics:\n

Name
 		Power
 		Version
 		Vendor
 
Settings: In this section the application preferences appear. These preferences are:

Language: it can be chosen from Auto, English, Spanish, French or Portuguese.
 			Sampling frequency: it can be chosen from the four different frequencies of sensors, ie number of samples per second.
 			Timer: time elapsed since we enter the graphics screen until it begins recording.
 			Recording time: length of the recording is chosen.
 About: this option shows information about device authors and privacy settings of the application.
 Help: application help.
Sensors with their measurements will be displayed on this screen. Screen structure:\n

Buttons of sensors information:
 	Accelerometer
 	Gyroscope
 	Magnetometer
 	Proximity sensor
 	Light sensor
 	GPS
 
Under each information button we can see:
 	Saving data option: press it if you want the sensor data are stored in a csv file. Several sensors can be selected for recording at a time.
 	Graphics Icon: this button will take us to the representation of the sensors.
 	Data show: measures taken by the sensors are shown in real time.
 In the section of GPS we can see a map shaped icon which replaces the icon of the graph. This icon takes us to a world map with a button on top. By pressing it, it brings us to our current location. To make the icon appear, GPS needs to be on.
 If you click on the menu, two buttons appear:
 			Sampling frequency: it can be chosen from the four different frequencies of sensors, ie number of samples per second.
 			Timer: time elapsed since we enter the graphics screen until it begins recording.
 			Recording time: length of the recording is chosen.
 About: this option shows information about device authors and privacy settings of the application.
 Help: application help.
The representation of sensors data appears on this screen.\n

Its structure is as follows:
 	Start Button: it will be pressed to start the graphic.
 	Pause/Stop Button: it will be pressed to stop or interrupt the graphical representation.
 	 Reset Button: it will be pressed to start a new representation of the graph.
 Below the buttons, it appears:
 	Checkbox: these measures may be selected or not depending on what data you want to display.
 	REC: it will be displayed in green if we do not press the Save Data button from Data measurements screen. If Save Data button is pressed, REC button will be displayed in red.
 	GPS signal: it shows GPS status. Searching, Off or Signal.
 	Graph: the data collected by the mobile are represented.
 Once started the representation, can switch from one sensor to another, share or save it in CSV format (menu).

On this screen all saved files obtained after the measurements are shown. We will find two different files on this screen:
 Sensors measurements: these are data obtained from the accelerometer, the gyroscope, the magnetometer, the light sensor and the proximity sensor.
 GPS: locations which are obtained while doing the recording.
 If a file is pressed over an extended period of time, it can be sent by the desired application.
 Once a file selected, if you want it to be removed from the mailing list, you only have to press over the same file until it remains unselected again.
Several files to be sent can be selected at a time.\n

In the Information Screen of sensors (gyroscope, accelerometer, magnetometer, light sensor, proximity sensor and GPS) basic information about each sensor is shown. Each screen is structured in this way:
 	About: explanation of what does it measure and what the sensor is.
 	How it works: explanation of how the sensor works.
 	Purpose : examples of use of the sensors.
 	What it measures: sensor measures taken by the sensor on the Android device.
